honestly, you can see the Republican platform and call Obama a narcissist?

This was delicious! I dont think I'd change anything. Could add some green veggies or a little chicken to make it a great take to work lunch.will look for a chewier noodle.

You know I didn't go to college but I've done pretty darn good considering. Started my own business 30 years ago, I employ 16 including myself ,my wife ,my son ,my sister inlaw, one polish imigrant ( now a citizen ) one black man, one married lesbian woman, a high school student, an ex con  and a few more..... None of whom graduated from college. I graduated from high school in 1973 . That high school diploma is the equivalent of a masters degree by today's standards.

What's sad today is that no President, including Obama, has the courage to ever admit they're wrong, so they all come off looking arrogant. That's one reason Obama is so disliked, but the same was true for Bush, who, when asked, said he couldn't think of a single mistake he'd made, and it's true for Hillary Clinton, as well, who even 20 years ago blamed "A vast right-wing conspiracy" for her problems.

All this makes it hard to sympathize with our leaders, or see them as truly human. And the reason they can't show themselves to be human is the ubiquitous media and endless TV campaign that highlights and exploits any sign of weakness. I've always admired JFK for saying, "I'm the responsible officer of the government" when asked to explain how things went wrong with Bay of Pigs, and Harry Truman for saying, "The buck stops here." But admissions like that would be torn apart today rather than being seen as signs of character.

I up voted your comment though I think the racism charge isn't nearly what you've stated. Seems to me that media and many others, by refusing to admit racism goes both ways, and showcasing incidents of white to black racism has painted a false narrative.

Whites are every bit in their right to point this out without being charged as racists. This, IMO, has really added to the charge of "systemic" racism in America.
What is your co Pay and how high are your deductibles? How are the doctors in your network? Lower premiums are sometimes not all they are cracked up to be.
Please, enlighten us on what constitutes, "a few more years"?  Five, Twenty?  Fifty?  (We've been in Korea for sixty-five years.  And we still have a presence in Germany after seventy years.)

ISIS "has gained a foothold in ungoverned spaces effectively in Syria and parts of western Iraq,” Wrong. Prior to being governed my ISIS, those spaces were governed by Syria and Iraq, respectively. But this administration was determined to see the Assad regime go, without consideration for the far worse warlords that would rise up in the territories Assad lost; and this administration was determined to bolt from Iraq, rather than providing the few more years of support that would have allowed Iraq's democratic institutions to successfully take root, and would have preserved our hard-won gains.

"This is not an organization that can destroy the United States.” Isn't that comment awfully reminiscent of how he called ISIS "a jayvee team"?

Balance and tolerance? Where do you get that from? His approach to Fergeson where a criminal was attempting to kill a policeman? He overlooked the fact that the majority of the rioters were bussed in from out of town. It was well known that ugly things were going to happen yet he kept the national guard away and let these hoodelems do serious damage to private businesses that could have been protected by the national guard! Balanced? He's quick to imply racial discrimination against him instead of considering that most of his decisions have done great damage to this country. His actions would bring the same criticism regardless of his color.

Or we could, let's see, change the law?

In many, many cases, we spend incredibly large amounts of money on very unfortunate children, who the average person would say will never benefit significantly with what we are spending to 'educate' them.

Again, limited funds. When we spend huge amounts of money on one very small set of children, we are actually taking that money away from the education of all the other children. Many more of whom would benefit from just a little bit more attention than they currently get. This is happening, every day.

Huh?  I'm talking to my fellow Democrats, who seem to think he should have the powers Trump claims he will have if he is president, which is just flat-out ridiculous.  Obama has faced nonstop opposition from day 1 with grace and humor and done what he could.

Accepting the fatality of our situation can be seen from two perspectives, personal and global.  The global merely reflects the personal, which has much greater weight.  With regard to the latter, personal acquisition gives us the illusion that we are immune from mortality.  It is a disease that has become the obsession of our time, dragging along the depletion of resources on a grander scale.  Humans cannot respond to this environmental crisis without first considering a substitute for rampant materialism.  Where do we find it, or more correctly, can we even consider it?  The unconscious alternative to materialism may be suicide.

A generation can be considered 25 years. 22 is close enough. The reporter was using a convenient and familiar marker to dramatize the length of time between Democratic administrations. You're splitting hairs.
A generation is twenty years so, yes, first Democratic mayor in a generation.
If your family has traditionally started having babies at age 16 . . . .

RE: Halfway into his four-year term as the city’s first Democratic mayor in a generation,

A generation is considered about 30 years (maybe a bit more now that people start families later.) There was a Democratic mayor 22 years ago.

Dr. K,
Senator Rubio is young, handsome, from Florida & he speaks easily in a convincing fashion in Spanish, so the establishment donors think that he has promise.

Like you, I am not a political scientist but I believe that the election will be determined by events not foreseen. A weather event, a new terrorist threat, etc.

Another candidate not yet mentioned is the former Governor of Ohio. Ohio is an important GOP & National Election state, so I think he has more promise for being a nominee than the other 12. The Senator from SC dropped out of the race.

Because of the compelling rhetoric of Mr. Trump (we have to stop and find out what's wrong) and Mr. Cruz who wants to start WWIII over Iran, it is likely that they have miscalculated the preferences of mothers to send their sons and daughters off to war.

GOP candidates are handicapped by their denial of global warming. While, there should be a lot of creative entrepreneurial ideas for reducing carbon combustion emissions but there are not. Mayor Bloomberg seems to be the most tuned in member of the GOP who might have a shot at a brokered convention. Mr. Bloomberg & Mr.Christie both know the devastation that can occur from a powerful storm surge so it could happen again before the election.

Remember we lose a lot of Americans on our highways each year. Our highway fatalities are greater than those from war. Also, bridges collapse and trains are derailed. I remind everyone of seismic events. They happen.

No.   Absolutely do not substitute cayenne pepper for Sichuan peppercorn.  Sichuan peppercorns are not peppercorns or even related to peppers!  They are the husk of a seed.  and the soft tofu definitely benefits from the incredibly easy step of steeping in salted water - why would you skip it?   Sichuan peppercorns are surprisingly widely available and absolutely integral to this dish.  If you can't find them, wait to make this until you do.

I had a similar epiphany recently. I'm a flutist and get little or no freelance work, and haven't tried especially hard to go for any. This is mostly due to snobbery: I don't like the music, I don't like the lack of preparation time, I don't like how some of my colleagues become so jaded and cynical about even the most glorious music, e.g., Bach's B Minor Mass. This year, a friend needed a sub for a small church job in an outer borough. We did Bach, Poulenc and a selection of Christmas songs arranged by the conductor. My colleague assured me that this was low pressure, and not to worry, but I felt bad about not having practiced more and given my own best. But I watched the choir -- composed of volunteers from the congregation -- and realized that this gave them and the other church members great joy. This was their connection to music, and I was there to help make their celebration special.

After that, I no longer cared about perfection quite so much.

Merry Happy Everything!

I cooked mine in an 8" round, and although I worried (based on the heaviness of the final product) that it would be dense and dry, it was actually nicely cake-y and crumbly--like a softer shortbread. Maybe worth it to seek out the smaller pan? I also took mine out of the oven before it was as dark as the NYT photo.

I swear I have heard the term "custard" used to apply to desserts not so pudding-like, but cannot recall the context.

Am making this again for Xmas morning!

The Far Breton is indeed a custard like desert. It is easy to make and a delight to bite into and quite unlike anything I've had in the USA. I like to make it with a drop of orange liqueur in the batter.
So,the Gateau Breton is a different thing entirely. What these desserts have in common is that they originate in Brittany. To add to the confusion, there is also a Breton Galette which is a type of pancake.. and a vast array of shortbread biscuits called Palets Bretons.

Agree on the food processor size but was trying to make two.
I only have 9"rounds, so loweredto 40 min. still, they both were pretty hard - between cake and shortbread cookie consistency.QUESTION- when i looked it up (google), however, they all talk about the Far Breton being a CUSTARD like treat -- that bears nothing to what I think this recipe has in mind; WHICH is right (custard or shortbread like), and how hard should this thing be?
